awd_titl_txt: Gyrokinetic Electron and Fully Kinetic Ion Particle Simulation of Collisionless Magnetic Reconnection
awd_abstract_narration:
This research continues investigation of 2-D and 3-D current sheet instabilities with a finite guide field, as in reality, and further extends and validates a gyrokinetic electon and fully kinetic ion model for the magnetic reconnection process. Magnetic reconnection is a fundamental process in laboratory as well space plasmas, attributed to be the underlying physical mechanism for major or minor disruptions of tokamak plasmas. The following specific science questions will be answered: (1) What are the linear eigenmode structure and spectral properties of instabilities generated in current sheet with various guide fields. (2) What are the properties of nonlinear instabilities and their roles in the anomalous resistivity in current sheet. How is the reconnection triggered locally in the presence of the guide field. (3) How does the reconnection evolve, and what is the reconnection rate in a large system, 2-D for now, that allows the presence of and interaction between multiple magnetic islands? Can the basic solutions of the Riemann problem, for structure of quasi-steady reconnection, be reached in system with various sizes and under various boundary conditions.
The innovative and advanced simulation tools developed for this research will have a much broader application to simulations of various nonlinear waves and wave-particle interaction in laboratory plasmas and physics of solar flares and transport in the magnetosphere. Since magnetic reconnection is one of the fundamental processes in magnetically confined plasmas, this research will certainly have an impact on research of fusion interest, where kinetic analyses of transport processes due to electromagnetic fluctuations in low-collisionality conditions is one of the challenging problems.
This proposal was submitted to the NSF-DoE Partnership in Plasma Science and Engineering joint solicitation 08-589. This award is being funded jointly by the Division of Physics of the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate and by Atmospheric Sciences Division of the Geosciences Directorate

The major goal of our project is to understand instabilities associated with magnetic reconnection in a current sheet with a finite guide field, as
in magnetic fusion devices and space plasmas. The challenge is that the global physics of reconnection demands that wave modes ranging from Alfven waves to lower-hybrid/whistler waves be handled on an equal footing, while keeping a realistic ion-to-electron mass ratio mi/me. Our research is
carried out by numerical simulations using our gyrokinetic electron and fully kinetic ion (GeFi) particle scheme.

In the proposal period, we have carried out the GeFi simulations of tearing mode instabilities in two dimensions (2-D) and the current driven instabilities in 2-D for a broad range of the guide field and a realsitic mi/me. The 2-D simulation has been performed  for a Harris current sheet with various guide field BG (BG/Bx0=0.5-20, where Bx0 is the anti-parallel field component), sheet half-width L, and electron-to-ion temperature Te/Ti. The linearized GeFi delta-f simulation results are compared with (1) Drake & Lee's asymptotic matching theory, (2) a GK eigenmode theory of the tearing instability developled by us, (3) results from our GeFi full-f simulation, and (4) results from a Darwin PIC simulation. The nonlinear GeFi results are also compared with the nonlinear Darwin results. Not only the tearing mode instability is investigated for a much broader parameter range than previous studies, but the GeFi scheme is thoroughly benchmarked and validated. It is found that in general the newly improved GeFi scheme is valid for BG/Bx0>0.1.

Then, a 2-D linearized delta-f GeFi simulation has been carried out for the current sheet instabilities to undertand the physics of 'mode B'
(Wang et al., PoP, 2008) at the center of the current sheet, which is of whistler/lower-hybrid type and thought to contribute to the anomalous
resistivity in magnetic reconnection. Meanwhile, a theoretical study has been carried out for beam-plasma interaction for the conditions consistent
with the Harris sheet center, to understand the origin of mode B.

After the 2-D simulations, instabilities in a Harris sheet have been calculated for the full 3-D system. By specifying a finite ky, the modification of the eigen modes of the 2-D tearing instability as a function of kx chas been obtained. By allowing a finite kx, the modification of the 2-D current driven instabilities as a function of ky are obstained. This full 3-D scan also sweeps
through the case with k dot B = 0. A complete profile of the 3-D unstable eigenmodes corresponding to various BG has been generated. Multiple unstable modes are found in the current sheet center as well as at the edges. The most unstable modes have been determined. 

As a continued effort of using GeFi model to investigate magnetic reconnection in laboratory and space plasmas, we have begun to simulate the reconnection physics associated with the sawteeth events in tokamak plasmas. The nonliner GeFi scheme is solved using the finite element method in a 3-D cylindrical domain, in which unstructured meshes with approximately equal areas are employed. A nonmonotonic q-profile is assumed, corresponding to the double-tearing instabilities. Meanwhile, a GeFi particle model for laboratory plasmas in a torus geometry has been developed to investigate magnetic reconnection/sawteeth in tokamak plasmas.
